briefing.opening: Good morning. Welcome to the Climate Change Daily Briefing for March 1, 2026. Today has been a day marked by active policy discussions and practical efforts to address climate change both domestically and internationally, alongside continued warnings about the actual impacts of climate change.

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Climate Policy and Legislation Trends
sections.content: Domestically, there are active discussions on establishing a policy framework and legislating measures to address climate change. Public discourse has officially begun regarding the 'Carbon Neutrality Framework Act,' which was deemed unconstitutional two years ago, drawing significant attention to its future deliberation process [4, 13]. Meanwhile, the Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries plans to focus on reducing fishing vessels, particularly in climate-sensitive sectors, and promote pilot aquaculture support as part of its climate adaptation efforts [2, 3]. Furthermore, on April 21, 2025, Chairman Han Hwa-jin is scheduled to host the opening ceremony of Climate Change Week at the National Climate Crisis Response Committee, which is expected to solidify the nation's commitment to climate action [1].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Domestic Societal and Industrial Efforts for Carbon Neutrality
sections.content: Concrete examples of practical efforts by local communities and industries to achieve carbon neutrality continue to emerge. Gimhae City is encouraging citizen participation by hosting a carbon neutrality practice competition [5], while Guri City Volunteer Center and the Korean Federation of Rural Women's Clubs in Yeoncheon County are also driving change in their communities through carbon neutrality projects and resolutions [6, 9]. Yongin Special City is recruiting participants for the 2026 Carbon Neutrality Point System in the automotive sector, contributing to the spread of eco-friendly transportation [7], and in Danyang County, a hydrogen charging station, a key infrastructure for achieving carbon neutrality, has officially commenced operations [8]. In the industrial sector, POSCO is realizing carbon neutrality with its innovative 'hydrogen reduction steelmaking' technology [10], and Saemangeum is seeing plans emerge for its development as a forward base for renewable energy and K-Food [12], indicating continued growth in the renewable energy sector [11].

sections.title: âš ï¸ International Impacts and Threats of Climate Change
sections.content: Internationally, warnings continue regarding the real threats and widespread impacts caused by climate change. Research indicating that Antarctic glacier melt ultimately does not help in combating climate change further exacerbates the severity of the issue [19]. Furthermore, climate change is causing disruptions to academic calendars [20], and according to one study, it is negatively affecting coffee crops, raising concerns about economic and social ripple effects [21]. The case of a woman in Ontario, Canada, collecting 1,300 bags of trash tells a story of pollution, climate change, and the Great Lakes, suggesting the complexity of environmental issues [22].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Research and Civil Society Climate Action
sections.content: Amidst these threats, international research and civil society efforts to address climate change continue. Past climate change research has indicated that tropical life forms showed resilience to changes up to 1.5Â°C [16], providing important implications for future climate adaptation. Furthermore, efforts are underway to help trees and cities get ahead of climate change [17], and reactivated Sunrise Movement chapters are actively responding to climate change [18], demonstrating a global spread of citizen-led climate action.

briefing.closing: In today's briefing, we observed diverse efforts to address climate change both domestically and internationally, while also reaffirming the clear need to recognize the realistic threats posed by climate change. It is crucial to overcome the climate crisis through continuous attention and cooperation. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.description: On May 21, 2024, the final public hearing date for a climate constitutional petition questioning whether the South Korean government's response to climate change aligns with the constitution, citizens, youth, and children, including the climate lawsuit petitioners, held a press conference in front of the Constitutional Court in Jongno-gu, Seoul, urging a declaration of unconstitutionality. Reporter Han Su-bin reported that last month, the public discussion process for amending the 'Framework Act on Carbon Neutrality and Green Growth for Climate Crisis Response (Carbon Neutrality Framework Act)' officially began...
